alert.note: Alert for East Carteret; Hatteras Island; Ocracoke Island (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 21 at 8:59PM EDT until September 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City
info.description: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM EDT THURSDAY THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THURSDAY TO 8 PM EDT FRIDAY... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THURSDAY TO 8 PM EDT FRIDAY... * WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6 to 10 feet expected in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves expected in the surf zone. * WHERE...East Carteret County, and Ocracoke Island and Hatteras Island. * WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory and High Surf Advisory, from 5 PM Thursday to 8 PM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from 7 AM EDT Thursday through Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Swell from Major Hurricane Fiona will bring dangerous surf to beaches from Cape Lookout North to south of Oregon Inlet. Seas build to 5-8 feet by late Thursday morning and then 6-10 feet by Thursday evening with seas remaining above 8 feet until Friday evening. Minor ocean overwash will also be possible across oceanside beaches including Rodanthe, Hatteras, and Ocracoke. Dangerous rip currents will be possible throughout the day, but may become most prevalent around the hours of low tide, which will be noon.
info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Inexperienced swimmers should remain out of the water due to dangerous surf conditions. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times.

area.areaDesc: East Carteret; Hatteras Island; Ocracoke Island
